status.full_text:
I'm moving back to Germanyüá©üá™. 
I had enough of how Norwegians just get along, are not bitching about everything, combine their job and family, go out for sport all week. 
This nature is just too much, colors, rocks, trees. WTFjords!
My German soul just can't stand this anymore.
@motor3d Oh, the agony!

I mean look at this! Who in their right mind wants to live here?!
#bergen üá≥üá¥ #backtoger üá©üá™ https://t.co/BHhsNLpkBf

That's why I love #JavaScript: use good syntax and let the engine optimize it for you (or it will be optimized soonish).

Don't use performance hacks, which make code less readable and remove portability. https://t.co/fNA4HpkND5
@rotnroll666 That weather was nearly the same today!
Hjem i #trondheim üá≥üá¥ https://t.co/4jAtY7OeqO
@jen_star It's so fantastic that we managed to move to Norway and just be a few hours apart! #norwayrocks

Bootstrap is made to be customized and offers a very straightforward way from prototyping with generic UI elements to a unique design. 

Also, the value of a unique design becomes very low when going a mobile first strategy, Bootstrap et al provide best practices. https://t.co/MfiSnWCpqy

Employing these best practices will make it easier form your users to understand the mechanics in your app.

Before rolling your own CSS framework think hard if it is really worth the effort.
Also think about the fact that developer onboarding becomes much easier when using a popular framework. Scaling your team with a homegrown solution becomes slower.

@Paratron Nah, it's just the widespread believe about what makes a secure password. 

It does not necessarily mean that they are storing passwords in plain text.

Best practice today is min-length without any character limitations plus 2FA.

For a telco, 2FA is basically free via SMS.
@Paratron Although it is important to know that SMS is not a secure transport. So don't use that for securing the keys to your kingdom.

#react tip: Don't store elements in state.

Your element tree is always a function of your state.
@Paratron There are always people learning, who might not have this mental model in mind ...
The ranking system on SO gives people incentives to vote down, to keep new people from entering the platform. https://t.co/1DBkvRbh62

I don't think it helps s community to have "ranks", it puts to much emphasis on past interactions of members.

I see the value of a evaluation system: to reward users.

But there are better metrics, like how many people did you help this week.

@_Tomalak You are equating help with activity.
It could also mean: "how many people have marked your past answers  as helpful this week"
@_Tomalak Yes, but SO is not using this as a rank, but the all-time total.

@c089 I don't go to the religious ceremonies except for funerals. 
For weddings there was always a non-religious-themed fest after the church stuff.

@c089 In some cases it was clear because they knew us, in others guests were asked to specify which parts we would participate in. So, even the religious one were aware that not everybody appreciates a religious ceremony.

@c089 I "believe" that I am doing them a better service, when I am not in there rolling eyes all the time. Most people will understand if you tell them: I'm happy to celebrate with you, but this part is not for me ...

@SamirTalwar @c089 I know, this is highly personal. I worked in defunct companies and there I tried to be approachable and trustworthy and create an environment which reduced pressure.

Here is what I have so far:

Ports & Adapters Architecture: https://t.co/9TmCi0HRE6 
Here is a video @totheralistair  explaining it: 
https://t.co/Mja82X5CIl
It gives a great intro how "Ports & Adapters" came to be, 2 more videos show them writing an implementation of this arch. https://t.co/6NF5M2bXJL

S.O.L.I.D. Principle: https://t.co/TOidvOqNt6
Following this enables a Ports & Adapters arch, and also testing.
This is my religion when it comes to writing code.

I like to evolve an solution through loosely coupling components, which in the end are microservices. 
The best explanation for this approach I found in "REST in Practice" https://t.co/NkMWwiyu91

Since we are implementing code in JavaScript, I am really missing a good book on good first principles in this language. We have fantastic books for JavaScript syntax and features, Promises etc. But I'm not aware of a book doing Architecture Archaeology in JavaScript projects.
This might be due to that fact that this language is running on everything, everywhere and every environment has it's specific properties which you need to cater for.
